headline: CNN Newsroom
subHeadline: Davis Talks about Nichols' Beating; Tyre Nichols' Stepfather Speaks About the Video; Tyre Nichols' Mother Speaks about His Death. Aired 9-9:30a ET

utterances.speaker: JIM SCIUTTO, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: A good Friday morning to you. A solemn day of news today. I'm Jim Sciutto.

utterances.speaker: ERICA HILL, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: And I'm Erica Hill.Today the nation will see exactly what happened to 29-year-old Tyre Nichols during a violent encounter with police in Memphis, Tennessee. The injuries he sustained during that traffic stop ultimately leading to his death. And some of those videos, including those from police body cameras, have been described as appalling, horrific and inhumane.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Right now five Memphis police officers have been fired, charged with several felonies, including second-degree murder. This morning, a remarkable one on CNN. CNN's Don Lemon spoke exclusively with Memphis Police Chief CJ Davis revealing extensive new details about what you're going to see in the videos that will be released later today. The two meticulously walking through what led up to the traffic stop and remaining questions about that, the beating and the arrest of Tyre Nichols.Also, the ongoing investigations into the officers responsible. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) CHIEF CERELYN "CJ" DAVIS, MEMPHIS POLICE: What was said was that there was a witnessing of what was considered reckless driving. We've looked at cameras. We've looked at body-worn cameras. And even if something occurred prior to this stop, we've been unable to substantiate that at this time. It doesn't mean that something -- something didn't happen -

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: That the cameras -

utterances.speaker: DAVIS
utterances.sentences: But there's no proof.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: There's no proof that the cameras didn't pick up.

utterances.speaker: DAVIS
utterances.sentences: That the cameras didn't pick up. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: The chief laying out just what happened over the course of these two incidents, emphasizing the physical interaction between Mr. Nichols and the officers started when those officers attempted to remove him from the car.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) CHIEF CERELYN "CJ" DAVIS, MEMPHIS POLICE: Well, from the very beginning, to me they were riled up, you know? I don't think they were as amped up as they were on the second -- at the second scene. But just the stop, the nature of the stop, very aggressive, loud, you know, communication. And it was -- it just rose from there. It escalated from there. Mr. Nichols was able to get away from these officers and they found him again at another location. And at that point there was -- there was an amount of aggression that is unexplainable, you know. In any instance where you're apprehending someone, even in the worst situations when there is resistance, officers still have the responsibility to exercise care and regard for any individual that's in custody or they're attempting to apprehend. And they're trained to do that.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You have to deescalate.

utterances.speaker: DAVIS
utterances.sentences: And to deescalate. And that's a piece, I think, that is in question. But I think the escalation was there from the officers before training even needed to come in as it relates to deescalate. The escalation was already at a high level.The video is broken into four different sort of fragmented pieces, but they're all very relative to this -- to this incident. The initial stop, the stop near Tyre's home, and also body-worn camera of individuals that were at that scene. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: It has been said that it is reminiscent, perhaps worse, than the Rodney King video. Is that your assessment?

utterances.speaker: DAVIS
utterances.sentences: That's my assessment.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: DAVIS
utterances.sentences: I was in law enforcement during the Rodney King incident. And it's - it's, you know, very much aligned with that same type of behavior.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That it's worse?

utterances.speaker: DAVIS
utterances.sentences: And sort of group think. I would - I would say it's about the same, if not worse.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: If not worse.

utterances.speaker: DAVIS
utterances.sentences: If not worse.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: About the same, if not worse.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: What so many of us will see later today when that video is released.Well, it's all of that, Chief Davis said, that led her to act immediately in response to -- and these are her words here -- this disregard for life.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: And as you just heard there, too, a response well beyond what was required in those moments.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) CHIEF CERELYN "CJ" DAVIS, MEMPHIS POLICE: I was -- I was outraged. I was -- it was incomprehensible to me. It was unconscionable and I - I felt that I needed to do something and do something quickly. I don't think I've witnessed anything of that nature in my entire career.

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: DAVIS
utterances.sentences: Really.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That bad?

utterances.speaker: DAVIS
utterances.sentences: It was that bad.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: What are we going to see, then? DAVISsee a disregard for life, duty of care that we're all sworn to and a level of physical interaction that is above and beyond what is required in law enforcement. And - and I'm sure that, you know, as I said before, that individuals watching will feel what the family felt. And if you don't, then you're not a human being. And we all are human beings. And I think there will be a measure of sadness as well. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: And CNN "THIS MORNING" anchor Don Lemon, as well as CNN's senior national correspondent Sara Sidner both joining us now from Memphis with more.Don, I just have to say, this was such a powerful morning, not only your interview with the chief, your interview with Tyre Nichols' family and also a defense attorney. And we're going to bring more of that throughout the morning.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: So I just want to make sure people stay with us for that.This interview, Don, with the chief, there was so much that came out of that in terms of details. The chief knowing right away that something was wrong here, that things were not handled properly, that there was no way to even see that there could be reckless driving. Were you surprised by how forthcoming she was in this interview, Don?

utterances.speaker: SARA SIDNER, CNN SENIOR NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Yes, Sara, that raises questions about the legal implications of those comments. You have the police chief saying, I expected serious charges, quote/unquote. She says, you're going to see acts that defy humanity in this video, quote/unquote. And she also notably says that they've not been able to substantiate reckless driving, which would have then justified, or at least been an explanation for the police stop.You spoke to the DA this morning. I wonder what - what the --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Hey, Jim, can I say something about reckless driving?

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, that reckless driving charge, we've heard that a lot on these stops.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That they -- when we do these stories. That reckless driving can be a catch all for anything.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Yes. For sure.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: What is reckless driving?

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: A blinker is out.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: A flasher is out. A head lamp is out.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You cross the line.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Maybe you're looking at a cellphone. You know, anything, you get distracted or something.So, I'm sorry, just, you know, the whole reckless driving, what - what would substantiate that. But I'm sorry to interrupt. Go on.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: No question. I mean, listen, you -- we had a police pull over justified by having a deodorant on the rearview mirror. You remember that case as well.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: But, Sara, I wonder how the D.A. is describing, first of all, next steps, but also how they're processing those public comments and they factor in to those next steps.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes, this morning I spoke at length with the Shelby County D.A. And we will have some of that for you later in the day.He said a couple of things. One, the first thing I asked him was, in plain speak, not in the language of the justice system, but in plain speak, did these officers beat Tyre Nichols to death? And he said yes.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Now, he would not go further as to what exactly happened because they have to be very careful. The D.A. is not the police chief, is not the defense attorneys, is not the public, is not the family. The D.A. has to be very, very careful about how he talks about this video and was very careful not to say everything that was on the video. But he agreed that this is how Tyre Nichols died at the hands of officers. He was beaten to death.That is a hard thing to hear for any of us.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: But for the family, and the unbelievable pain that they have to be feeling, and we saw that in your interview that was excellent, that is going to stick with them for the rest of their lives. And this video may stick with all of us for the rest of our lives.Secondly, I asked him if there was any evidence that he saw of reckless driving. In other words, do they have any of that video? And he said, you will not be seeing any of that. We are still investigating. But what is being released will not show the lead up to this. And lastly I said, did the officers lie on the police report or lie to the police department, because we now know from your interview that they told the family that it was a DUI -

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Yes. SIDNER

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: And as the family said, as the mother said, this looks like a cover up. That's how she saw it.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Yes. You know, Erica, echoes of the first police report in the George Floyd case, right? Certainly, did not have the details that we later saw in the video.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: It's true. You know, and in the -- when we think about the family, Don, your interview with Tyre Nichols' mother, his stepfather, their attorney this morning was to powerful. I was - I was struck by the strength of Mrs. Wells. Struck by her grace, frankly.She has not watched that full video.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Her husband did. He told you, Don, he didn't - he didn't want her to see it all.But the fact that we know, and we haven't seen it yet, but the fact that he confirmed that it ends with Tyre Nichols calling out for his mother, just feet, frankly, from the home -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: What was your take away from that? Again, it was so powerful. Just I - I am in awe and -- of the strength of this family to come out and talk about it. And yet it's so necessary and it is so sad that we are here yet again, Don, where a family has to talk about this moment that they should never ever be in.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Listen -- listen, there -- there's a lot here. Let me just say -- and it's not, you know, you, Erica. I didn't want to say in the interview "stepfather," because I grew up with a stepfather.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And my stepfather didn't think he was my stepfather. He was like, I'm his dad.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And he - you know, Mr. Wells referred to Tyre as his son.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So I wish - look, I know technically it's correct, but I wish as a network we stopped calling him a stepfather because he wasn't a step away, he was the guy's dad, he's the guy's father.The other thing is that I -- when I sat there I forgot that I was in an interview. I was just talking to a mom and a dad, right, in the interview. And I don't know if you -- I could not -- I didn't have return, which is, in TV language, I couldn't see what was on the air because I was talking to them. I just didn't -- I wasn't able to see. But I don't know if you guys saw, when he was describing what was in the videotape, she looked away. She couldn't even look at him. She was flinching because she didn't want to hear what happened to her son. So, he described what happened. I think the most important part is when he talked to -- talked about seeing the lack of care from the fire department and from the officers. And they're walking around smoking. And that they propped his son up and then used expletives when he slumped over. So, here is some of this. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) RODNEY WELLS, TYRE NICHOLS' FATHER: He said, what did I do? Why are y'all doing this to me? What did I do? And they proceeded to snatch him out of the car and was trying to wrestle him to the ground. And he got scared. So, he was athletic enough to get out of their situation and run. And he was trying to run home because we were -- he was three blocks from the house when they stopped him. So, after the initial encounter, we didn't see everything because actually when the body cam started they were already engaged. And then there was the second body cam with the sky cam that videoed the encounter. And when I saw the police officer -- you know they have this little like stick, this metal thing that they pull out.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, pull out, like an antenna-style, right?

utterances.speaker: RODNEY WELLS
utterances.sentences: Uh-huh, like an antenna. Exactly.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Retractable.

utterances.speaker: RODNEY WELLS
utterances.sentences: Yes.. And I saw them pull that out and started beating my son with it. I saw officers hitting on him. I saw officers kicking him. One officer kicked him like he was kicking a football a couple of times. And -- but the most -- the most telling thing about the video to me was the fact that it was maybe ten officers on the scene and nobody tried to stop it or even after they beat him and -and they propped him up against a car, no one rendered aid to him whatsoever. They walked around, smoking cigarettes like it was all calm and like, you know, bragging about what happened and - LEMONRODNEY. WELLS: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And you saw him just sitting there?

utterances.speaker: RODNEY WELLS
utterances.sentences: He was sitting there and then he slumped over. And an officer walked over to him and said, sit back up. Mother - MF, you know.And while he's handcuffed. So he had to -- they propped him back up and he slumped over again and they propped him back up again, but no one was rendering aid. I saw some fire department people come out there and they just walked around. Nobody showed him any aid. And they're supposed to be trained in first aid. By the time the paramedic truck pulled up, this is when we couldn't see anything because the paramedic truck blocked the camera. So, I was told that the lady who was driving the paramedic truck never got out. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That - that was hard. That was hard, Erica and Jim, to sit there and listen to, you know, someone who's -- you remember Freddie Gray, Sara?

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I do.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: When they talked about not rendering care and, you know, what happened in the Freddie Gray case.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Right. In Baltimore.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: In Baltimore. And it's just - and they were just -- I would imagine that's the charges, the reason for the charges for the fire department, but that was very tough.Another very tough part, when she said she went to the hospital and saw her son, immediately she knew, she said, my son will never be the same if he lives. He's going to be a vegetable. That his face was swollen up, his nose was like an "s." And I - you know, I mentioned, I said, it reminded me of Emmett Till. And the dad said, yes, that's what it was like. That's why he took the picture there.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, we've seen that picture and we're going to see the video.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I've talked with the community and they have said they don't even want to watch the -- some of them don't want to watch the video.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: A lot of us don't want to watch the video.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: But they will. And we're hoping that it doesn't further injure the people that have to deal with this. The family has asked for calm. They, so far, have gotten it.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: They pray (ph) for handling this with care.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And, Erica, listen, I didn't mean to chastise you. As a -- as someone who grew up with a stepdad, I know how he hated being called a stepdad because he would say, you're my son, you're not my stepson, you're my son. So, I just - you know, they're human beings and I just (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Look, I - you -- there was no chastising and, you're right, you know, one of my two mother-in-law's would say the same thing about her stepson, my husband, he is her son. And so you're absolutely right, Don, this is Tyre Nichols' dad.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: This morning, as this country braces for the video set to be released later today of the violent encounter between 29-year-old Tyre Nichols and five Memphis police officers, a video that's been described as horrific, heinous and inhumane by the police chief. Nichols died three days after the injuries sustained during that arrest.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: CNN's Don Lemon spoke to Tyre's parents in their first interview since charges were announced against five police officers involved. They described seeing Tyre for the first time in the hospital. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You wanted first-degree murder charges.ROWVAUGHN WELLS, TYRE NICHOLS' MOTHER: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You didn't get that.

utterances.speaker: ROWVAUGHN WELLS
utterances.sentences: No. The charges that were filed against those officers are good charges. Those are the charges that I feel will stick. And so I'm happy with the charges that the district attorney has set forth.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Mom, when did you first learn about this? How did you hear?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Why do you say that?
